description: The main job of any CEO is to set the strategy and ensure they have the right leadership team in place.

html:
Understanding the different types of leadership teams and their roles in executing specific strategies is essential for any CEO. By assembling the right team for your strategy, you can ensure your company’s success and growth in a competitive market.

Having the right team in place not only improves the execution of the strategy, it also boosts morale and fosters a culture of innovation and excellence. CEOs should regularly assess their leadership teams, ensuring they remain aligned with the company’s strategic goals and are equipped to handle emerging challenges and opportunities. 

Different strategies require different types of leadership teams. Here are four types of leadership teams every CEO should consider, depending on their strategic focus.

1. Innovation teams

These teams are essential for creating new products and services to market. Innovation teams are the lifeblood of any company looking to stay ahead of the competition through new product development. Members of these teams are typically creative thinkers and risk-takers willing to push boundaries. They are also highly collaborative, working closely with other departments to bring ideas to fruition.

A tech startup will need an innovation-focused team to develop a new app that addresses an emerging market need, involving designers, developers, and market researchers. This cross-functional team ensures that every aspect of the new product is carefully considered, from user experience to technical feasibility.

2. Expansion teams

To take existing products and services to new markets, expansion teams are responsible for identifying and entering new geographic or demographic markets. They aim to grow the company’s footprint and customer base by leveraging existing products and services.

Key members of these teams are market analysts who can identify potential new markets and understand their unique characteristics. Skilled negotiators are also crucial for establishing partnerships and navigating new market regulations.

For example, a consumer goods company will want an expansion team to enter the Asian market, tailoring the company’s products and marketing strategies for success in this new region. This team would study market trends, local regulations, and consumer behavior to ensure a smooth and successful entry into the new market.

3. Growth teams

These teams focus on strategies to increase the company’s market share and scale its operations efficiently. Growth teams work on optimizing sales strategies, enhancing customer engagement, and improving operational efficiency. They rely on data analytics to make informed decisions and track progress. Data-driven insights help the team identify opportunities for growth and areas needing improvement.

For example, a software-as-a-service company aiming to increase its market share might create a growth team to optimize its sales funnel, improve customer retention strategies, and streamline operations to handle increased demand. This team would use customer data to tailor its approach, ensuring that marketing efforts are targeted and effective.

4. Optimization teams

Focused on honing processes to maximize profitability, optimization teams analyze current operations, identify areas for improvement, and implement changes to reduce costs and enhance productivity. These teams are process-oriented, using methodologies like Lean or Six Sigma to refine processes. They are highly analytical, identifying inefficiencies and measuring the impact of changes.

A manufacturing company might form an optimization team to review its production line processes, reducing waste and increasing output through lean manufacturing techniques. This team would thoroughly assess each step in the production process, finding ways to eliminate waste and improve efficiency.

Understanding the different types of leadership teams and their roles in executing specific strategies is essential for any CEO. By assembling the right team for your strategy, you can ensure your company’s success and growth in a competitive market.

Having the right team in place not only improves the execution of the strategy but also boosts morale and fosters a culture of innovation and excellence. CEOs should regularly assess their leadership teams, ensuring they remain aligned with the company’s strategic goals and are equipped to handle emerging challenges and opportunities.

The opinions expressed here by Inc.com columnists are their own, not those of Inc.com.
